Apple scab.description: Fungal disease causing olive-green to brown velvety spots on apple leaves and fruit; reduces fruit marketability and can cause early leaf drop.
remedies: Remove and destroy fallen infected leaves in autumn.
Apply registered fungicide at green tip and petal-fall according to local extension guidance.
Use resistant cultivars and promote air flow (prune, proper spacing).
Apple scab.confidence_notes: Visual diagnosis reliable when lesions are classic; confirm with temporal history (wet spring).

Bacterial spot.description: Bacterial disease on tomato/pepper causing small dark lesions on leaves and fruit, often with halo; favoured by warm, wet conditions.
visual_cues: Necrotic lesions on fruit with chlorotic halo
remedies: Avoid overhead irrigation; use drip irrigation and improve canopy ventilation.
Remove and destroy severely infected plants/fruit.
Use certified disease-free seed/stock and copper-based sprays where recommended (rotate products).
Bacterial spot.confidence_notes: Bacterial vs fungal can be confused visually; lab confirmation recommended for ambiguous cases.

Black rot (Grape).description: Fungal disease of grape producing round dark lesions on leaves and black shriveled berries; spreads rapidly in warm wet seasons.
remedies: Prune out and destroy mummified berries and highly infected tissue.
Apply protectant fungicides on schedule during susceptible periods.
Maintain air circulation and reduce humidity in the canopy.
Black rot (Grape).confidence_notes: Distinct fruit mummification helps identification; consider lab confirmation if unclear.

Cedar apple rust.description: Rust fungus with a two-host life cycle (juniper and apple/pear) causing bright orange gelatinous lesions on leaves and deformities.
visual_cues: Bright orange gelatinous spore horns on leaves (spring)
Yellow to orange lesions with red borders
Cedar apple rust.likely_cause: Fungal (Gymnosporangium spp.) with alternate juniper host
remedies: Remove nearby junipers if practical or remove galls from junipers.
Apply fungicides at key apple phenology stages if orchard history indicates rust.
Cedar apple rust.confidence_notes: Visible orange spore horns in spring are diagnostic.

Gray leaf spot (Cercospora) / Cercospora.description: Fungal disease causing rectangular tan/gray lesions on grass/corn leaves; reduces photosynthetic area and yield under heavy pressure.
remedies: Rotate crops and bury infected residue where feasible.
Apply fungicides at recommended growth stages for high risk fields.
Use resistant hybrids and manage nitrogen levels and canopy density.
Gray leaf spot (Cercospora) / Cercospora.confidence_notes: Typical rectangular lesions on corn are reliable visual cue.

Common rust (Corn).description: Rust disease of corn producing orange-brown pustules on leaves, more common in cooler, moist conditions.
visual_cues: Orange to brown pustules scattered on leaf surface
remedies: Manage field conditions to reduce prolonged leaf wetness.
Fungicide in severe outbreaks on susceptible varieties.
Common rust (Corn).confidence_notes: Pustules are diagnostic; distinguish from southern rust by pustule color/location and timing.

Early blight.description: Fungal disease in tomato/potato producing concentric 'target' lesions on leaves and fruit; worsens with age and poor sanitation.
visual_cues: Concentric ringed lesions (target-like) on leaves and stems
Fruit lesions dark with target pattern
remedies: Remove infected debris and volunteer plants.
Use crop rotation and resistant varieties when possible.
Apply protective/curative fungicides based on disease pressure.
Early blight.confidence_notes: Concentric ringed lesions are classic and reliable.

Esca (Black measles).description: Complex of grapevine trunk diseases causing wood decay, foliar tiger-stripe symptoms and shriveled dark berries.
remedies: Remove and replace severely affected vines; prune out dead wood.
Improve sanitation and wound protection practices.
There are no simple curative sprays; manage planting material and pruning hygiene.
Esca (Black measles).confidence_notes: Diagnosis may require wood inspection or specialist confirmation.

Huanglongbing (Citrus greening).description: Serious bacterial disease of citrus caused by Candidatus Liberibacter species, vectored by psyllids; causes yellow shoots, blotchy mottling and bitter fruit; often fatal.
Huanglongbing (Citrus greening).likely_cause: Bacterial (Candidatus Liberibacter spp.) transmitted by Asian citrus psyllid
remedies: Remove infected trees and control psyllid vectors aggressively.
Plant certified disease-free nursery stock and follow integrated pest management.
There is currently no cure; management focuses on containment and vector control.
Huanglongbing (Citrus greening).confidence_notes: Requires lab testing for confirmation; symptoms overlap with nutrient deficiency but are asymmetric.

Late blight.description: Rapid, destructive disease of potato and tomato causing water-soaked lesions and gray mold; favored by cool, wet weather.
visual_cues: White fuzzy sporulation in humid conditions
remedies: Remove and destroy infected plants promptly.
Apply recommended fungicides protectively in cool, wet conditions.
Use certified seed potatoes and follow sanitation practices.
Late blight.confidence_notes: Rapid spread and classic sporulation help diagnosis; lab confirmation recommended for high stakes.

Leaf mold (tomato).canonical_name: Fulvia fulva (formerly Cladosporium fulvum) - leaf mold
Leaf mold (tomato).description: Fungal disease on tomato causing yellow patches on upper leaf surface and olive-green growth on the underside; thrives in high humidity.
visual_cues: Leaf curling and defoliation in severe cases
remedies: Reduce greenhouse humidity and improve ventilation.
Remove infected leaves and avoid overhead watering.
Leaf mold (tomato).confidence_notes: Under greenhouse conditions this is common and fairly diagnostic.

Leaf blight (Isariopsis / Grape leaf bli.description: Fungal-like leaf lesions on grape characterized by necrotic spots that may coalesce and cause defoliation.
visual_cues: Small necrotic spots that expand and coalesce
Lesions often dark with yellow halo
remedies: Sanitation of infected debris and pruning to improve airflow.
Fungicide sprays according to local recommendations during wet seasons.
Leaf blight (Isariopsis / Grape leaf bli.confidence_notes: Visual diagnosis can be aided by local disease history.

Leaf scorch (Strawberry/others).description: General symptom of marginal leaf browning and necrosis; can be due to fungal, bacterial, or abiotic stress (heat, salts, water stress).
visual_cues: Sharp demarcation between healthy and burned tissue
Often starts at leaf edges and moves inward
Leaf scorch (Strawberry/others).likely_cause: Abiotic stress or pathogen depending on context
remedies: Check irrigation and soil salinity; adjust watering.
If pathogen suspected, collect samples and consult extension for testing.
Improve canopy microclimate and nutrition to reduce stress.
Leaf scorch (Strawberry/others).confidence_notes: Leaf scorch is a symptom, not a single disease; treat underlying cause.

Northern leaf blight.description: Fungal disease producing cigar-shaped lesions on corn leaves; reduces photosynthetic area and yield.
visual_cues: Long cigar-shaped tan lesions parallel to leaf veins
Lesions may coalesce under heavy infection
remedies: Plant resistant hybrids and rotate crops.
Use timely fungicide applications for susceptible hybrids under high disease pressure.
Northern leaf blight.confidence_notes: Lesion shape makes this one relatively easy to identify visually.

Powdery mildew.description: Surface fungal growth appearing as white powdery patches on leaves, stems and fruit; common across many crops.
visual_cues: White dusty coating on leaf surfaces
Distorted growth and chlorosis near colonies
Powdery mildew.likely_cause: Fungal (Erysiphales family â€” species vary by crop)
remedies: Apply foliar fungicides and improve airflow.
Avoid excessive nitrogen that promotes dense foliage.
Powdery mildew.confidence_notes: Distinct white powdery growth is diagnostic.

Septoria leaf spot.description: Fungal disease of tomato causing small circular spots with dark borders and gray centers, leading to defoliation in severe cases.
visual_cues: Many small circular spots with dark border and pale center
Starts on lower leaves and moves up canopy
remedies: Remove lower infected leaves, improve spacing and ventilation.
Rotate crops and avoid wet foliage; use fungicides if severe.

Spider mites (Two-spotted spider mite).description: Sap-sucking mite causing stippling, webbing and bronzing of leaves; favored by hot, dry conditions.
visual_cues: Fine webbing on underside in heavy infestations
remedies: Use predatory mites or biological controls where feasible.
Avoid high dust and hot dry stress; use proper irrigation.
Apply miticides only when thresholds exceeded and rotate modes of action.
Spider mites (Two-spotted spider mite).confidence_notes: Look for webbing and mobile mites on underside of leaves for confirmation.

Target Spot.description: Foliar disease producing round to target-shaped lesions; affects a range of crops under warm, humid conditions.
visual_cues: Lesions may coalesce and cause defoliation
remedies: Improve airflow and reduce leaf wetness.
Remove infected debris; apply fungicides if recommended for the crop.
Target Spot.confidence_notes: Target shape is clue but species differ by crop; verify with local extension.

Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus (TYLCV).description: Begomovirus transmitted by whiteflies causing leaf curling, yellowing and severe yield loss in tomato.
remedies: Use resistant varieties where available and control whitefly vectors.
Remove infected plants promptly to reduce spread.
Use reflective mulches and insect-proof screens in high-value production.
Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus (TYLCV).confidence_notes: Requires vector and symptom correlation; lab test confirms.

Tomato mosaic virus.description: Stable virus causing mottling, leaf distortion and reduced yields; spreads mechanically and via seed in some cases.
remedies: Remove and destroy infected plants; sanitize tools and hands.
Use certified virus-free seed and resistant cultivars where available.
Tomato mosaic virus.confidence_notes: Lab confirmation recommended; strict sanitation is key.

Cassava mosaic disease.description: Viral disease causing deformation, leaf mosaic patterns, stunting and major yield loss in cassava.
Cassava mosaic disease.likely_cause: Cassava mosaic begomoviruses transmitted primarily by whiteflies and infected cuttings.
remedies: Use resistant varieties like TME series
Cassava mosaic disease.confidence_notes: Very common in sub-Saharan Africa; mosaic pattern + stunting is highly indicative.

Cassava brown streak disease.description: Virus disease causing brown necrotic rot inside cassava roots and leaf chlorosis.
Cassava brown streak disease.likely_cause: Ipomovirus transmitted mainly by whiteflies and infected planting material.
Cassava brown streak disease.confidence_notes: Root necrosis upon cutting tubers is the strongest indicator.

Maize lethal necrosis.description: Synergistic viral infection causing severe chlorosis, stunting and near-total crop failure.
Maize lethal necrosis.likely_cause: Maize chlorotic mottle virus + another potyvirus, spread by insects.
Maize lethal necrosis.confidence_notes: Distinct sudden leaf necrosis + stunting; common in East Africa outbreaks.

Banana Xanthomonas wilt.description: Bacterial wilt devastating banana and plantain in East/Central Africa.
visual_cues: Milky bacterial ooze from cut stem
Banana Xanthomonas wilt.likely_cause: Xanthomonas campestris pv. musacearum bacteria spread by tools, insects and infected material.
Banana Xanthomonas wilt.confidence_notes: Bacterial ooze and premature fruit ripening are classic signs.

Bean rust.description: Fungal rust infection affecting common beans, causing leaf pustules and early defoliation.
Bean rust.likely_cause: Uromyces appendiculatus fungus favored by humid conditions.

Bean common mosaic virus.description: Viral disease leading to mosaic patterns, leaf malformation and reduced yield.
Bean common mosaic virus.likely_cause: Potyvirus transmitted by aphids and infected seeds.
Bean common mosaic virus.confidence_notes: Mosaic with leaf deformation is typical.

Groundnut rosette disease.description: A virus complex causing stunting, mottling and severe yield loss in groundnuts.
Groundnut rosette disease.confidence_notes: Very common in West Africa; symptoms well understood.

Sorghum anthracnose.description: Fungal disease forming leaf lesions and stalk rot in sorghum.
Sorghum anthracnose.confidence_notes: Red margins around lesions are typical.

Rice blast.description: One of the most destructive rice fungal diseases globally.
Rice blast.likely_cause: Magnaporthe oryzae fungus under humid conditions.

Rice bacterial leaf blight.description: Bacterial disease causing yellowing, leaf blight and yield loss in rice.
visual_cues: Yellow stripes from leaf tips downward
Rice bacterial leaf blight.likely_cause: Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzae spread by rain and irrigation.

Tea mosquito bug damage.description: Serious pest of cashew, cocoa and tea in West Africa.
Tea mosquito bug damage.confidence_notes: Feeding spots with halos are unique.

Cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus.description: Virus infecting cowpea, passionfruit and legumes.

Okra leaf curl disease.description: Whitefly-transmitted virus causing curling and stunted okra.

Sweet potato weevil damage.description: Infestation causing root tunneling and leaf wilting in sweet potato.

Sweet potato feathery mottle virus.description: Virus causing leaf mottling and reduced tuber yield.
Sweet potato feathery mottle virus.likely_cause: Potyvirus spread by aphids and infected vines.
Sweet potato feathery mottle virus.confidence_notes: Feathery mottling differentiates from nutrient stress.

Plantain black sigatoka.description: Fungus reducing photosynthesis in plantain and banana.

Pear leaf blister mite.description: Tiny mites causing blistering and deformation of pear leaves.
Pear leaf blister mite.confidence_notes: Blistering makes this easy to identify.

Cotton bollworm damage.description: Major defoliator and fruit borer of cotton and many crops.

Citrus leaf miner damage.description: Miner larvae create serpentine tunnels in citrus leaves.

Pear scab.description: Fungal leaf and fruit disease similar to apple scab but specific to pear.
Pear scab.confidence_notes: Lesions resemble apple scab but host-specific.

Mango anthracnose.description: Fungal disease causing fruit rot and leaf spots on mango.
Mango anthracnose.confidence_notes: Black sunken fruit spots are distinctive.

Mango mealybug.description: Sap-sucking pest causing sooty mold and fruit drop on mango.

Avocado root rot.description: Soil-borne rot causing wilting and root decay in avocado.
Avocado root rot.confidence_notes: Root examination is key for confirmation.

Pigeon pea sterility mosaic disease.description: Major pigeon pea viral disease causing sterile plants with pale leaves.
Pigeon pea sterility mosaic disease.likely_cause: SMD virus complex transmitted by mites.

Millet downy mildew.confidence_notes: Green ear symptom is highly specific.

Sun scorch / heat stress.description: High-temperature stress causing leaf burn and fruit sunscald.

Wind damage.description: Physical stress due to high winds causing leaf shredding and lodging.

Iron deficiency chlorosis.description: Nutrient disorder causing interveinal chlorosis on young leaves.
Iron deficiency chlorosis.likely_cause: High pH soil limiting Fe availability.
Iron deficiency chlorosis.confidence_notes: Confused with Mg deficiency, but Fe hits young leaves first.

Magnesium deficiency.description: Nutrient shortage causing interveinal yellowing of older leaves.
Magnesium deficiency.likely_cause: Low Mg in soil, high K competition.
Magnesium deficiency.confidence_notes: Age of affected leaf differentiates from Fe deficiency.

Phosphorus deficiency.description: Stunted, purplish plants due to low phosphorus.
Phosphorus deficiency.likely_cause: Low soil P or cold soils.
Phosphorus deficiency.confidence_notes: Purple coloration is a strong sign.

Calcium deficiency (blossom end rot).description: Calcium shortage in fruiting crops leading to dark sunken spots at fruit ends.
Calcium deficiency (blossom end rot).likely_cause: Inconsistent watering causing Ca mobility issues.

Zinc deficiency.description: Micronutrient disorder causing small leaves and rosetting.

Salt stress / salinity injury.description: Salt buildup causing leaf burn and poor growth.
Salt stress / salinity injury.likely_cause: Irrigation with saline water or poor drainage.
